Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Filtrations of Boolean algebras and related structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
Geschke plans to study applications of filtrations of Boolean algebras, Banach spaces and C-star-algebras to problems in measure theory, functional analysis, set-theoretic topology and topological dynamics.
Filtrations can often be used to construct automorphisms of or homomorphisms from the structures under consideration.
In other cases, interesting properties of a structure can be characterized in terms of the existence of a filtration of a specific type.
The following topics will be considered: Cofinalities of Boolean algebras, C-star-algebras and Banach spaces, automorphisms of the Calkin algebra and other C-star- and Boolean algebras, Borel liftings for measure and category with a large size of the continuum, the structure of phase spaces of minimal dynamical systems.

Many natural questions about properties of certain infinite structures cannot be decided using the usual axioms of mathematics.
This is where logic and set theory have to be used to analyze the situation.
Boolean algebras are sufficiently nice, so that set-theoretic methods can be applied very directly in order to answer questions about them.
Understanding this interaction between Boolean algebras and set theory helps in getting the right intuition about applications of set theory to questions about more complicated structures.
Large structures can often be analyzed by breaking them into smaller pieces that fit together nicely.
This approach has been particularly successful with Boolean algebras.
Therefore it should be applied systematically to study other infinite structures as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My award was scheduled to end at the end of May, 2012, and an extension was granted until the end of August. This report concerns outcomes during this period. I attended the XV SLALM (Latin-American Symposium in Mathematical Logic) in Bogota, May 30-June 8, 2012. I gave a mini-course ("Determinacy and inner model theory") that was expanded into an expository paper with the same title. The paper should serve as an introduction to this area of research, which aims at developing tools to compare the strength of mathematical theories where, roughly, this strength is measured in terms of how difficult it is to verify their consistency. 

In addition to the paper above, another one (coauthored with Richard Ketchersid) was finalized and submitted. It concerns how complex certain classification problems are. This is traditionally studied in terms of very concrete definable objects, while our paper studies versions of these complexity results in the most general setting possible (in a precise sense).

Work on these papers during the Summer was supported by the grant. I was informed that a paper submitted a few months prior (coauthored with Martin Zeman) has been accepted for publication. The research in this latter paper compares the universe of set theory (the collection of all sets) with some smaller (inner) models of set theory, and draws conclusions on how much these models resemble the universe based on some technical "closeness" assumptions. Zeman and I are now investigating extensions of this research (involving the area known as descriptive set theory). A research visit of Zeman to the author was sponsored by the grant. Finally, the author continued a few other projects, still in progress, that originate in prior research of the author and his collaborators, also sponsored by the grant.
